text:
I was arguing with my university teachers that they don't need to invent their own "pseudo-code" for algorithms to make it look "clean" enough because they can just use Julia. The counter-argument was that when you invent your own "pseudo-code", it gives you certain freedom when defining algorithms, thus it's necessary to use that kind of syntax instead of some real programming language.

I almost got them to approve my example Julia function as a valid "pseudo-code" (they didn't know that it's actually Julia code), but for some reason, the way how loops are defined, `for i = 1:n`  was not good enough. A teacher didn't understand does the loop end to `n` or `n-1`. However, if written like in their "pseudo-code" approach,  `for i = 1 to n` , is was somehow more "clear". Everything else was almost acceptable. `push!` was "questionable operation", but `append!` was ok. `f(x) = 2*x` was "not understood", but `f = x -> 2x` was ok.

text: "inventing your own" pseudo code just screams having to learn a billion different conventions & syntaxes - hardly seems like a goal that's actually good to achieve..

elements.text: "inventing your own" pseudo code just screams having to learn a billion different conventions & syntaxes - hardly seems like a goal that's actually good to achieve..

text: The "pseudocode" that is an informal convention is actually ALGOL-based - it has roots in a real programming language

elements.text: The "pseudocode" that is an informal convention is actually ALGOL-based - it has roots in a real programming language

text: More often than not it leads to subtle or not-so-subtle semantic errors as well. More often than not this kind of homebrew pseudo code isn't internally consistent either

elements.text: More often than not it leads to subtle or not-so-subtle semantic errors as well. More often than not this kind of homebrew pseudo code isn't internally consistent either

text:
I agree. If you invent your own pseudo-code, you need to invent your own syntax. And the argument that "pseudo-code is good because it works even if you don't know some particular programming language" doesn't work because you need to learn the syntax of some pseudo-code that is not even used anywhere.

I feel a little bit frustrated because from my point of view, they just already decided that they need to use pseudo-code, and find some "reason" why e.g. Julia's syntax is not clear enough. I really don't understand how `for i=1:5` is somehow more unclear than `for i=1 to 5`, and how using the latter one makes more sense and the first one is somehow confusing on does the loop end to `n` or `n-1`.

text: Building off <@U677NAWV8>'s point, pseudo code does not mean non-standard code. For example, Guy Steele spent some time trying to categorize and pull out common patterns from CS and mathematical usage of pseudo code: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dCuZkaaou0Q>. IMO something like this makes a lot more sense if you're writing something that is _meant to be read by others_.

attachments.title: What is the notation for a stepped range
attachments.text: I am searching for a notation which represents a (closed) integer range in certain steps. A step size of 4 in the interval $[-4\ldotp\ldotp 12]$ would produce: $\{-4,0,4,8,12\}$

text: macros in pseudo code?! preposterous!
Print Fibonacci numbers to 34: `for i in @seq [0, 1, 1, 2, 3, ..., 55)`

If it has a clear standard and unique interpretation then it is not pseudo-code, it is a programming language (without implementation but still a programming language). To me the whole point of pseudo code is the ability to be sloppy and still have people understand what you mean because people are smart and good at understanding other people from incomplete information.

text: Steele's proposal of `'(lambda ,vars ,body)` reminds me of our `f.(a, Ref(b), Ref(c))` pattern for stopping broadcasting

One lesson I relearn often is that representations which are clear to me in my notes or head, are not usually clear to others. If you make your own pseudo code (or data viz) you’ll make dozens of little compromises, assumptions, and decisions about what makes sense, but it’s all through your personal lens, with all your blind spots. I try to avoid it unless I’ve run it past two other people and they like it.
